author: Joa Axelsson

text:
Comments like these sadden me greatly. FF 8, 9 and X were all great, even better than 7 in their own ways. I think it is still a good game and most of what makes 7 so highly praised today is the nostalgia factor. 7 was the first of its kind and did a lot of things well, but I wouldn't say it was the best FF game by a long shot. 

I would agree that the newer games have been lackluster. Square Enix is too focused on making new features than creating lovable characters and immersive plots.
author: Kyle Sands

text:
Nostalgia plays a part in everyone's life, and for many this was their first Final Fantasy. However, it was also perhaps one of the more surreal. While all the PSX era games had static, pre-rendered backgrounds, I'd argue that this game had perhaps the most colorful, unique, and creative of the bunch. Forgotten city was so mysterious in its looks, the song only compounding such a bizarre location (what the shit lived in that giant conch?!). The very sound of the OST had such a unique flare, perhaps due to restrictions, giving it a more artificial, if unnatural sound other Square rpgs had at the time (Legends of Mana!) which in my opinion made the experience all the more enthralling. 

The world map had a grey tint to it by the end, with the somber music and the fact the world was ending all fit so perfectly together, like many things did. (other ff games did this too, even 6 before it, but still it worked!) Everyone will have their favorites, but this game did a lot of things right at the right time, from unique characters like Red XIII, to the bizarre enemies that covered the world. As others said above me, this game brought JRPGs to their countries, that wasn't by mistake.

Final Fantasy 6 is perhaps one of my favorites, and I can understand people hating on 7 after the shift from sprites(or believing others loved the game simply because it was 3d, even if characters looked pretty bad and it always bothered me that they had no mouth) but even with the weak push when it came to the polygons.. the background, atmosphere, and many mechanics just worked and elevated it from such faults to the point where I could forgive it

 It's not all nostalgia, and I'd disagree when you say it isn't the best "By a long shot", because I'd put it right up there with 6, 8, 9, and Tactics, which perhaps had one of the best stories imo. Strange, pre-rendered machinery filled several backgrounds, ghosts in the abandoned train-yard, the swinging guillotine guys in the abandoned mansion.. the thrill of finally climbing the Shinra tower... finding Lucrecia's Cave... looking for that damn key item at the dig site. All of it just created a strange, yet unforgettable world later games just didn't do the same (though don't get me wrong, they did things in their own way, and did it quite well). The setting of the game opened up so many possibilities for uniqueness that they used. The other games setup a very specific theme and stuck with it, it was less of a mess and more direct, which is fine, but 7 kept that perfect blend of fantasy and technology that 6 was pushing as well, while at the same time being sloppy, yet surprisingly well kept. 

TLDR: It just saddens me when I see comments like this when it truly boils down to ones own opinion, and what they got out of their experience with this, and any other game. I've played every Final Fantasy (except 12) Yes, even 11 and 14 quite passionately, we're not all blind by nostalgia when there is truly something to enjoy. Frankly, you're making it seem like you simply know something everyone else doesn't, but it doesn't quite work that way. I spent just as many hours in 8, 9, and 10 as I have in 7, each a big part of my life. Opinions.

We know what we like, and I'd put 7 right up there even with its lacking story, the comical villain that was Sephiroth, and the disgusting yet silly character of Don Corneo.. why? Because the game is fun, and that's what matters in the end.

Cheers for a three year necro.
author: Rain

text: ​@Rain 7 was my first, but I liked 8 better. 7 is a masterpiece but overrated at the same time.

author: Vindel Mauser

text:
For me the power of this piece isn't so much the first time you come here (Aeris' death) but the second. Her death is confusing at first and seemingly pointless, but when you return, you learn why she did what she did, and what she sought to accomplish. Even though you have the answers now, the despair remains; we learn that, even if meteor is stopped, there may still be no hope for humanity.

"Meteor, weapon, everything will disappear. Perhaps, even ourselves."

Truly a chilling implication.

I really hope they don't remake Final Fantasy 7. Lets consider the differences in FF games from then till now. No more airships, linear paths, lack of side content, lack of character development, they turned Cloud into an emo like in KH and FFAC, bad voice overs, bad stories and even worse endings.

Those people over at square enix believe that if you have pretty pictures then that makes an awesome game. I like FF7 and if they remake it I know it won't be the same.

text: Final Fantasy VII changed my life, like so many other gamers. I wasn't new 2 games, I wasn't even new 2 RPG's. I'd been gaming since I was 4 & I played this at about 15. That first time you played, the first time the music tweaked your soul. It never leaves you..& it never will. This more than anything is why 7 will always be the best.

text:
@TheRetroPrime FFVII is slow, like all RPG's are. It's not repetitive, far from it. Characters are a subjective thing. The game spends a lot of time developing each character. As for freedom, you can literally travel the entire world, visit every city/village/cave at any time during the game. Hundreds of weapon/armour/items/spells to carry.

Maybe you should try playing it. As you clearly have no idea what you're on about.
author: CaptainAtomSmasher

text:
I hope they don't remake FFVII. It would only be a further raping of the game. You don't see Nintendo going around remaking Mario, Metroid or Zelda games. Enhancements, yes, but they further the franchises and continue to make great games. Square-Enix can't make a good game anymore, so the just continue to milk the old great games.

Anyway. They can't remake this game, and keep the same scope. It's just not possible to make a game of that size. It would be too massive.
author: CaptainAtomSmasher

text:
@TheRetroPrime Ocarina of Time isn't a RPG, so it's hard to compare to the two. And taste plays a much larger role, along with nostalgia. FFVII is my favorite game of all time. Is it the best? No, it's not. There is no best game, and I'm getting sick and hearing over and over that OoT is the best game ever made. 

So stop this damn tribalism, and appreciate both games, as they are clearly (no matter which one is superior) superb games.
author: CaptainAtomSmasher

text: FF7 haters are a reactionary measure by an indifferent group of people who were uncomfrotable with the fact that certain people have been content to soundly see perfection where imperfections lie. This game is clearly closer to flawless than it is flawed.

text:
@riznich
Say what you will. I don't think Final Fantasy VI is the best game ever. It's not the best RPG ever, either. I prefer it over the rest in the series, but saying it is the most overrated game in the series is not true. Final Fantasy VII and Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time are the most overrated games ever made, therefore rendering your point moot. They're not bad games by any stretch, but they aren't perfect, as most reviews of them suggest.

author: Lunarisultros

text:
I think the first impact of this song came from the fact that this was the first new song you'd heard for a hell of a long time.
You'd gotten used to the town music, overworld music, action music, battle music, boss music etc...then suddenly, this tune comes out of no-where and you're like "Bwuh? This is.....interesting."

Of course, nostalgia now dictates this music is important for another reason.

author: Stickanamehere

text: The whole atmosphere at this point in the game was one of suspense, and this music caught the mood perfectly.  The fact that you're just a short distance south of the snowfields adds a chilling tone to the land here.  Makes me think of hiking up Mt. Hood as a kid, up on rocky ridges that were just a short distance below the timber line and the snow line.  The land near the Forgotten City is very subalpine or subarctic looking.
author: ComradeSephiroth

text: What about a third group, that's just neutral?
author: dancekumquat

text: 4 continued)... better than COD right? You seem very intelligent, i just think you are looking at final fantasy VII from a very negative perspective. I'm not trying to discredit your opinin, but can you suggest an RPG you find to be better than FFVII either modern, or from the wheareabouts of FFVII's time period?
author: LOUMAYN

text: 4) the materia system was something that has nver ben used in a RPG before. i found that no other RPG has a system where you level up/junction items to gain magic has been better. and the plot is far more than just a cute girl who was innocent, and tbh most games dont have a deeper plot than this at all. Also i regret saying your a probs a COD fanboy that was an unfair prediction. Just because COD has sold the more games doesnt mean it is better. u probs can find a game less sold, howver...
author: LOUMAYN

text: 3) although some peopel may find it unbelievable, so what? final fantasy has always been if you would like to put it, somewhat of a 'fantasy'. however thier are very real issues in the game. such as the way the planet is dying. although it isnt in the same way. in real life there are very signigificant issues such as global warming which i why i feel that i can sort of relate.
author: LOUMAYN

text: 2) Yes  they may not have used the most advanced technology to record it. but i still prefer the whole soundtrack to much newer RPG's e.g lost odyssey
author: LOUMAYN

text: okay im sorry didnt know you went into a wole 6 paragraph argument, just saw it now. and tbh although i do agree with some of the things you say, it is not true at all. i checked some of the tracks from castlevania SOTN nd yeah they have a good style, seem very ahead of its time, but none of them seem to be emotional, atmospheric, or even memorable. i still dont understand how u can say FFVII's music is anti-atmospheric.
author: LOUMAYN

text: hahaa i pity you for thinking i have only played FF as an rpg series and for thinking that that ff7 is mediocre. it is far better than that and you are too arrogant too understand it. but go on im interested, why do you think ffvii is only mediocre?
author: LOUMAYN

text: 6) this is the funniest part. you assert that I must be a COD fan and an RPG hater if I dont like FFVII. that just shows that you know nothing about RPGs. I have played nearly every RPG to hit the American and European market. That is why i can say with certainty that FFVII is overrated garbage. your pretentious fanboy mind just cant comprehend that FFVII is, objectively, a very average and unimpressive game. you think FFVII is all that there is out there, and  I pity you. enjoy your mediocrity.
author: arbitor365

text: (5 continued). your problem is that you, good sir, are a pretentious anime fanboy kid. so, all it takes to get your attention and draw emotion our of you is style and melodramatics. you have no understanding of character depth and real plot development. so, all the creators have to do to leave an everlasting impact on you is to throw in a cute girl with no personality outside the realms of innocence and purity, kill her off and throw in some sappy music. "Naive" is the perfect word FFVII fans.
author: arbitor365

text:
(2 continued). its not a matter of opinion. technologically the sound track was far behind it's generation. look at castlevnia SOTN. look at panzer dragoon. both of them had actual real-life composed works and used much more advanced synth technology years before FFVII.

3) now, im not saying that technology makes the song better, but frankly most of the songs were not unique, not memorable, not composed with a high degree of complexity and (once again) they were not atmospheric at all.
author: arbitor365

text:
1) it is not a masterpiece (for the reasons I listed above). just becuase something is popular, that doesnt make it art. Modern warfare 2 sold way more games. so I guess that must mean that its a masterpiece and is better than FFVII right???

2) the music is anti-atmospheric. in fact, I felt that it killed the mood in many scenes that had potential. it sounds like a someone is off screen with a fife and an 70's keybourd. that style was fine for the 16 bit age but standards were raised by 1997.
author: arbitor365

text: well objectively, the storyline is broken, the characters are underdeveloped and the filler side-quests kill the experience. plus the music was sub-par for the console and generation it was on. just listen to castlevania SOTN, panzer dragoon, and countless other sega Saturn titles. FFVII's music half the time was very anti-atmospheric and sounded like it was done on a 1980's keyboard. overall, the music is like the game. shallow, sub-par and overrated. it just wasnt in any way, a "great" game.
author: arbitor365

text: FFVII doesnt deserve a spot on any music top 100 list.

author: Terraflyer

text:
FFX was good. Would've been worlds better if Tidus wasn't there.

I can't believe anyone said X is equal to VII though...thats just not right. No game, ever, in history, will be equal to VII. Nothing could ever hold a candle to FFVII. In terms of plot development, twists, musical score, character development, and in-game content (secrets and weapons, that sort of deal) FFVII is still definitely my favorite game to date.

Even in the world of COD Modern Warfare, Oblivion and Assassin's Creed.

text: I believe this is quite possibly his most successful composition to date. It conveys and evokes all of the proper emotions that the player likely feels at this point in the game. I remember when I first heard this song; I knew something wasn't right... something big was about to happen.

text: Not sure that's possible. You can listen to the melody and take what pattern it conforms to as the "right" interpretation, but i think the ambiguity might just be intended perhaps to add extra depth to the music. If you could get ahold of Uematsu's manuscripts/scores you'd be able to find out from whatever time sig he specified, but i'll leave that to you ;D

text: finalfantasy 7, for me brings back lots of memories. lot's of questions, and some answers. the first time i played that game i was 8 and knew nothing, but that game always made me think and it still dose. sometimes it makes me wonder if some how the world for us, could die as well, or if man kind would actually extend that far to make the world die faster, i'm just glad, i can't hear the real earth crying out in pain, because were reckless with it

text: In my opinion and I've been playing games now for some 20 years FF7 is peerless. The story, the characters, the music and the setting. I've played many brilliant games and many that are masterpieces but nothing will ever beat the feeling I got the first time I played this game. Just hearing the music brings back happy memory's and makes me want to play the game though for the millionth time.
